user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_Stub_IsValueCompatible:
```c
bool UT_Stub_IsValueCompatible(const UT_RetvalConfigEntry_t *Rvc, const char *WantTypeName, UT_ValueGenre_t WantGenre)
{
    bool IsCompatible;

    /* If the type names were specified on both sides, and they match, then the value is compatible */
    if (Rvc->TypeName != NULL && WantTypeName != NULL)
    {
        IsCompatible = (strcmp(Rvc->TypeName, WantTypeName) == 0);
    }
    else
    {
        /* The types are not _directly_ assignable, but it could possibly be coerced */
        IsCompatible = false;
    }

    /*
     * As an alternative/fallback, if the value genre is known for both sides,
     * check if coercion is a possibility.  For example, this could apply if the
     * value was int32 on one side and int16 on the other.
     */
    if (!IsCompatible && Rvc->Genre != UT_ValueGenre_OPAQUE && Rvc->Genre == WantGenre)
    {
        /* Genre match - should be compatible, with a potential size adjustment */
        IsCompatible = true;
    }

    return IsCompatible;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_Stub_IsValueCompatible:
const char *string
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the entire UT_Stub_IsValueCompatible function and related symbols. There are no calls to memcmp (direct or via an obvious wrapper) anywhere in the function. The only string comparison used is strcmp(Rvc->TypeName, WantTypeName) which is the correct Standard Library function for comparing null-terminated strings; Rule 21.14 prohibits memcmp for null-terminated strings, but no memcmp usage is present. The code also performs explicit NULL checks on the string pointers before calling strcmp, so there is no risk of passing NULL to the string comparison routine. Therefore there are no fragments that require investigation for violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14.
